We are excited to begin the 2020-21 school year virtually alongside your child. This letter provides an overview of what to expect as we continue to prepare for our first day of school on Mon., Aug. 31. Building-specific communication will be shared next week that will provide more information about the teaching and learning process.

Our educational model is built to include as many students as possible with live teacher-directed instruction (often referred to as synchronous learning.) In addition to live learning, our learning management system, SchoolsPLP, allows for recorded and interactive lessons (referred to as asynchronous learning.) In either method, students can expect teacher-directed instruction (either live or recorded) and coursework contained within modules through SchoolsPLP.

Read more: http://www.lhschools.org/protected/ArticleView.aspx?iid=63A2PP0&dasi=4GUII

There has been plenty of rain and dreary, gray skies of late, but that can't keep Juanita Dean down.

"I've never seen her with a frown on her face, even when she was wearing gloves and a mask for the cancer," said Licking Heights transportation supervisor Darlene Mortine. "She still had a smile on her face. She's sunshine. She's goes into all the buildings and always stops to talk to people. She's a wonderful employee who's willing to do whatever we ask of her. She truly cares for people, and the kids love her."

Dean is working on her seventh year as a van driver and sometimes school bus assistant for Licking Heights. She picks up special needs kids at home in the morning, then takes them home after school. In between, she works as a cook at Reynoldsburg High School. Mrs. Dean, affectionately known as "Miss Juanita" at Heights, has found a real home at the district after a career filled with many jobs, and is this week's Newark Advocate Difference Maker.

February 3 at 7:15 PM ·

As next school year approaches, this is the first in a series of letters I am writing to provide updates regarding the 2020-21 school year. One of the most frequent questions I am asked is: “Will the new high school open on time?” The answer is “yes” the building will open on time for the 2020/21 school year. In fact, as of this week the project is 60 percent complete. Also, as a reminder districtwide all students will see overcrowding relief as we will now be dividing our total student population by six buildings (instead of the current five buildings).

The Board of Education recently reviewed the following district reconfiguration and master schedule. A variety of factors were considered regarding school hours, including districtwide transportation needs and city traffic concerns.
